title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
US companies have urged President Moon Jae-in of South Korea to release Samsung chair Lee Jae-yong from prison.

Lee is serving an 18-month sentence for bribing Park Geun-hye, the former South Korea president, but the US companies argue that the billionaire executive could boost Joe Biden's efforts to shake off American dependence on computer chips produced in foreign countries.

Samsung is weighing multibillion-dollar investments in semiconductor facilities in the US, with the Seoul-based group considering sites in Austin, where it already has one chipmaking factory, as well as Phoenix and New York.

Among the early initiatives of his presidency, Biden unveiled a $50bn plan to boost the US semiconductor industry. But the focus on resurrecting America's self-sufficiency in computer chips has intensified after a global shortage in chips used in cars has begun to hit other industries, too.

In results released on Wednesday, network equipment maker Cisco highlighted the shortages of semiconductors, saying they were pushing up costs throughout the supply chain.

Moon will be accompanied by executives from South Korean companies on a visit to the White House on Friday and are expected to make announcements about investments in the US in semiconductors, batteries and electric vehicles.

Coronavirus digest

  • In Japan bank branches have been swamped by pensioners trying to cash stimulus cheques sent by the US Internal Revenue Service in an apparent error.

  • EU member states have provisionally agreed to allow entry to tourists who are fully vaccinated against Covid-19. The bloc's first anti-fraud prosecutor has warned of a “lot of troubles” as it prepares to police corruption in the €800bn pandemic recovery fund.

  • Boris Johnson said there was “increasing confidence” that coronavirus vaccines were effective against all variants, including a strain identified in India. Britain is preparing to give third booster shots in the autumn, with a clinical trial that will assess the effects of seven different jabs.

  • A rise in black fungus cases in India has exposed the consequences of overmedication as doctors flout guidelines and panicked patients self-medicate.

  • New Yorkers are keeping their masks on, writes Gillian Tett. In a group setting, it signals allegiance to shared civic values and responsibilities.

Follow the latest on our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

In the news

Fed considers tapering asset purchases Officials argued that the US central bank should chart a path towards curtailing some of its vast monetary support if the recovery accelerates further, according to minutes of the Federal Reserve's April meeting.

  • An array of companies have highlighted “tremendous inflation” in the costs of labour, freight and some raw materials in recent earnings presentations. But executives are unclear whether shortages and rising prices point to a short-term economic summer heatwave or a longer period of dangerous inflation.

Apollo Global co-founder to step down after Athene deal Josh Harris, one of the co-founders of US private equity group Apollo Global Management, will step down from day-to-day involvement in the firm after it merges with its insurance affiliate Athene, the company said on Thursday.

US targets ‘stable, predictable' ties with Russia Antony Blinken, US secretary of state, and his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov met on Wednesday in Reykjavik for what was the first face-to-face contact between the Biden administration and Vladimir Putin's Kremlin. Both countries have made steps to dial back tensions since agreeing to a Putin-Biden meeting, which is likely to take place next month.

Biden urges Netanyahu to end assault on Gaza In a White House readout from a call on Wednesday, Joe Biden told his Israeli counterpart that he “expected a significant de-escalation today on the path to a ceasefire”. Hours after Biden's statement, Benjamin Netanyahu said he was “determined to continue this operation until its aim is met”.

ByteDance chief to step down Zhang Yiming, ByteDance founder, will step down as chief executive of the group in the latest retreat from the limelight by a Chinese tech leader. Zhang, 38, founded ByteDance almost a decade ago and steered the Beijing-based group that has developed hit apps including TikTok and its sister Chinese platform Douyin.

JPMorgan funds invested in US private prison operator's debt Two years after JPMorgan Chase announced it would no longer finance the private prison industry in the US, the bank's asset management arm has disclosed a position in a private prison bond sold last month. Funds tied to the bank have invested $25m or more in a bond issued by CoreCivic, which runs prisons and detention centres across the US.

Brazil's police target environment minister Brazil's supreme court on Wednesday granted federal police access to the home and bank records of environment minister Ricardo Salles as part of an investigation into alleged collusion with illegal loggers in the Amazon.

The day ahead

Arctic Council Ministerial meeting This year's meeting will be held in person in Reykjavik, with Antony Blinken, US secretary of state, and Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov attending along with indigenous leaders and other ministers.

  • Rivalry between global powers is heating up in the Arctic and that is cause for concern, writes Tony Barber.

Oatly IPO Shares in the vegan food and drink maker will begin trading today after it raised $1.4bn in an initial public offering, giving the Swedish company a valuation of $10bn.

McDonald's annual meeting Pay will be on the menu for shareholders at the fast-food chain's annual meeting, particularly the salary of former chief executive Steve Easterbrook who was fired in November 2019.*

Argentina's farmers prepare to strike The nine-day strike begins over a month-long suspension of beef exports aimed at controlling spiralling inflation.

Nicolas Sarkozy to go on trial again France's former president goes on trial again, along with 13 co-defendants, for allegedly having illegally financed his unsuccessful 2012 re-election campaign.

What else we're reading

Bitcoin: ‘A dirty currency' No climate activist has had such a profound impact on the awareness of fossil fuels burnt to mine cryptocurrencies as Elon Musk, the Tesla chief executive who last week reversed plans to accept bitcoin as payment for vehicles. To academics, however, Musk has simply pointed out an established truth, albeit in his eccentric manner.

  • Cryptocurrency markets swung in chaotic trading on Wednesday. FT Trading Room editor Philip Stafford talks to the FT News Briefing podcast about yesterday's chaos.

  • Yes bitcoin is crashing but you can now buy “bitcoin pizza” with . . . dollars, writes Jemima Kelly in Alphaville.

Where is all the US bank M&A? With US interest rates near zero and weak demand for loans the conditions are ripe for takeovers in the financial services sector. But with valuations “in ‘oh my God' territory” targets are too expensive, say M&A bankers. The price rises are even more acute when it comes to newer, digital banks.

Joe Biden can help break N Ireland's Brexit deadlock A bipartisan group of members of the US Congress is calling on Biden to help break the present deadlock in Northern Ireland by appointing a special representative. The idea draws a hostile reaction in Downing Street, where Johnson's aides talk privately of “interference”. Biden should brush aside such objections, says Philip Stephens.

Welcome to Diller Island It took nature thousands of years to create the island of Manhattan. It took Barry Diller a decade and $260m to create his own island just off the shore of Manhattan. It finally opens on Friday after years of lawsuits, engineering challenges and fraught debate about the role that billionaires should be permitted to play in shaping New York City's public spaces.

What happens when virtue-signalling enters corporate life The case of Antonio García Martínez, who was recently fired from Apple, is a reminder of the extent to which virtue-signalling social activism is seeping into corporate culture, writes Jemima Kelly.

Nine-figure sums back at art auctions A series of recent art sales in New York boosted the overall market by $1.3bn across just three evenings. Momentum now moves to Hong Kong where Art Basel opens its first in-person fair since the pandemic began and where Christie's holds its jam-packed spring sales. Galleries in Europe are beginning to reopen as well.

Podcast of the day

Myanmar on the brink The military coup in Myanmar threatens to roll back a decade of democratisation. Gideon Rachman this week talks to Thant Myint-U, a Burmese historian and political analyst, about the situation in Myanmar and whether the country risks becoming a failed state.

*An earlier version misstated the date of Easterbrook's firing
